results.title: Teachers of the world. Part 2
results.brief_description: Globalisation of information, new technologies, the changing nature of our lives, are factors forcing educators everywhere to face an unprecedented period of reassessment. The teachers in this video are meeting this challenge head-on. “Korea” : a teacher uses drawings and cartoons to teach geometry. “United States of America” : an history teacher creates an experimental learning situation to foster an understanding of social injustice in her students. “Poland” : a teacher has his students exploring tradition and cultural taboo in relation to change and compromise.

results.title: Teach me what?
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Peter Johnson, Camfilm Productions and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Shows the Army Apprentices School as an institution that trains boys for a career in the Army as tradesmen. Includes a variety of trades open to young men, and shows extra-curricular activities and the opportunity for sport. The story endeavours to humanise the Army and to dispel some preconceptions.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Tea growing in Assam
results.brief_description: Shows the stages in the cultivation and processing of tea. A map shows the tea-producing areas of the world; Assam is taken as an example and scenes show workers planting out the young seeds and plants. Pruning, weeding and plucking are seen, and the factory processes described by animated diagrams. From Assam the tea goes to Calcutta and London, where it is blended with tea from other countries.

results.title: Te Rua
results.creator_credit: Barry Barclay, John O'Shea, New Zealand Film Commission and Pacific Films
results.brief_description: An angry, passionate, albeit stylistically flawed, film about the the theft by cultural institutions of objects sacred to indigenous peoples. A museum in Berlin refuses to return carvings which were stolen from a Maori tribe one hundred years earlier. Cutting between Berlin, where a highly charged political debate over the return of indigenous art is raging; and a remote Maori community in rural New Zealand, the film focuses on the different strategies of a young performance poet and his wealthy lawyer uncle, both from the Uritoto tribe, to restore the carvings to their people. While the older man attempts to work within the system to convince the museum’s director to return the sacred objects, the younger man resorts to radical action in Berlin. Meanwhile the elderly matriarch of the tribe begins a hunger strike in the marae meeting house that she vows to continue until the mission of returning the carvings to their rightful guardians is accomplished. Cast includes Wi Kuki Kaa, Gunter Meisner, Nissie Herewini, Matiu Mareikura, Tilly Reedy, Peter Kaa.
